description: Grove describes Kutzialflöte as �an open Flute of 4', 2' or sometimes 1' pitch, occasionally found on German organs from Praetorius onwards, evidently imitating a Slav instrument (cewzial: �flute�).� Seidel and Hamel, by way of Audsley, describe it as an open stop of 4', 2', 1', and sometimes 1-1/3' pitch. Wolfram, also by way of Audsley, calls it a small-scaled flute of 4' and 2' pitch. Maclean says that its tone �is said to have resembled the Waldflöte�. Adlung calls it rare, appearing at fifth and octave pitches.
examplesDescription: We know of no examples of Kewzialflöte, which is mentioned only by Maclean. Contributions welcome. The only known examples of Kutzialflöte are those cited by Audsley:

examples.name: Kützialflöte 1', Great; Church of St. Dominick, Prague, Czechoslovakia.
